text: Imagine a place in space where gravity is so strong that not even light can escape. That’s a black hole! Think of it like a cosmic vacuum cleaner, sucking in everything nearby. But how do they form? Let’s dive into the mystery of these invisible space monsters!
image_prompt: A black hole in space with swirling light and stars being pulled into it, set against a starry background.

text: Black holes are born from massive stars. When a star runs out of fuel, it collapses under its own gravity. If it’s big enough—like 20 times the size of our Sun—it crushes into a tiny point called a singularity. Boom! A black hole is born. It’s like a giant star turning into a tiny, super-dense dot.
image_prompt: A massive star collapsing into a black hole, with explosive energy and a bright supernova in the background.

text: Black holes are invisible because light can’t escape them. So how do we find them? Scientists look for their effects, like stars orbiting ‘nothing’ or X-rays from hot gas spiraling in. It’s like hearing a lion’s roar in the dark—you can’t see it, but you know it’s there!
image_prompt: A telescope observing a star being pulled by an invisible black hole, with distorted light around it.

text: Not all black holes are the same. Stellar black holes are a few times the Sun’s mass. Supermassive ones, like at our galaxy’s center, are millions or billions times heavier! Imagine a bowling ball versus a mountain—both are dense, but on totally different scales.
image_prompt: A comparison of a small stellar black hole next to a gigantic supermassive black hole, with scale indicators.

text: What happens if you fall into a black hole? You’d stretch like spaghetti—a process called ‘spaghettification’! The gravity near your feet would be way stronger than at your head, pulling you apart. Don’t worry, though—you’d never actually get there. It’s just a wild thought experiment!
image_prompt: A cartoon astronaut being stretched into a long, thin shape near a black hole, with a humorous tone.

text: Black holes aren’t eternal. They slowly lose energy and evaporate over billions of years, thanks to ‘Hawking radiation.’ It’s like a ice cube melting in the sun—just way, way slower. But don’t wait around; most black holes will outlast the universe!
image_prompt: A black hole with tiny particles escaping it, symbolizing Hawking radiation, in a cosmic setting.

text: In 2019, we saw the first-ever image of a black hole! The Event Horizon Telescope captured the supermassive black hole in galaxy M87. It looks like a fiery donut with a dark center—the shadow of the black hole itself. A huge leap for science!
image_prompt: The famous orange-and-black donut-shaped image of the M87 black hole, glowing with fiery light.

text: Black holes can collide! When two merge, they create ripples in space-time called gravitational waves. In 2015, scientists detected these waves for the first time. It’s like hearing two cymbals crash together in space—but with gravity instead of sound!
image_prompt: Two black holes spiraling toward each other, merging and sending out ripples of gravitational waves.

text: Could a black hole swallow Earth? No need to panic! The nearest black hole is thousands of light-years away. Even if one replaced our Sun, we’d orbit it just like normal—though it’d be very cold and dark. Black holes are scary, but they’re not lurking around the corner!
image_prompt: A comparison of the solar system with the Sun and a hypothetical black hole of the same mass, showing Earth’s orbit.

text: Black holes are some of the universe’s most mysterious objects. They challenge our understanding of physics and spark endless questions. What’s inside? Could we travel through one? The more we learn, the more we realize how much we don’t know. Stay curious—the universe is full of wonders waiting to be discovered!
image_prompt: A diverse group of students looking through a telescope at a starry sky, with a black hole visualization in the distance.
